newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian tourism chief throws out welcome mat.
newsitem.headline: Australian tourism chief throws out welcome mat.

text.p: Australia's tourism chief on Thursday urged all Australians to show a friendly face to Asian visitors, saying the nation's race row endangered its most valuable export industry.

Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) managing director John Morse said the country's friendly image was at risk over the "Hanson issue", referring to far-right lawmaker Pauline Hanson's calls for curbs on Asian immigration.
"There's never been a greater need nor a greater opportunity for Australia to demonstrate just how friendly and welcoming this country can be," Morse told a conference in Melbourne.
"If we lose our image as a friendly and welcoming country, then our whole tourism industry is at risk."

Morse was speaking before next week's Australian Tourism Exchange, a major trade fair where travel companies from around the world, many of them Asian, shop around for Australian holiday packages to offer their customers.
The government's ATC estimates business worth A$2.1 billion (US$1.58 billion) will be written at this year's fair.

Asia, excluding Japan, is the fastest-growing source of visitors for Australia's A$16 billion tourism industry. Japanese tourism to Australia is declining but still accounts for a fifth of all visitors to the country.

The anti-immigration backlash led by Hanson has alarmed the industry. Since Hanson warned last year that she felt Australia was in danger of being "swamped" by Asians, some Asian tour groups have cancelled trips to Australia, fearing racial abuse.
Australia's Tourism Task Force, a tourism industry lobby group, has urged the government to fund an Asian publicity campaign to counteract the offshore publicity given to Hanson.
But Morse said old-fashioned hospitality and a smile would do more than an advertising campaign to reverse the harm done to Australia's image in the region.
"I've adopted the habit now of talking to people in the street who are Asians...," Morse told Reuters. "You can see their faces light up."
